climbs.name: Winter Harvest
climbs.fa: Kenny Parker, Kevin Parker, and Eddie Begoon

content.description:
Deceptively difficult - a "Sunday drive" with a major roadblock.

Waltz up to stance below roof. Proceed briefly into thin dihedral. Make challenging clip and move left sequentially to arete (crux). Cruise left side of arete to top.
content.protection: 6 bolts. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
Left side of Puppy Chow area. Left of mega-classic testpiece/arete

Mango Tango (5.13d/14a),

left of waterfall, past 3 mixed routes. Starts on stairstepped rock below obvious corner dihedral.

content.description: This is a very good quality route that would benefit from more traffic.   Although the rock is clean, there are many small friable edges that still exist.   Use caution when stepping on them.   To start, either stick clip the high first bolt or just climb up on crimps and place a piece in a horizontal below the first bolt.   After the first bolt, arch a bit to the left and then slowly head back right passing bolts 2 and 3.   The technical crux is in the lower portion of the route.    After the 3rd bolt, head straight up through the overhanging face.   It's pumpy up there if you don't find the right holds quickly.
content.protection: 3 bolts, shuts.   A light rack.  Mostly smaller cams and nuts.   Cams to up to a #1 Camalot.
content.location: As you walk left along the Moon Wall, continue about 200 yards beyond the 2nd waterfall.   You will come to an orange face with a bunch of boulders at the base of the cliff.   This route starts from the boulders, just to the left of a tree.

content.description: Start up the initial crack of Death by Chewing Insects. Then ride the trio of horizontals directly to the right. Follow the very short vertical crack through the bulge. Then head up and right via plate jugs to the runnel on the arete. Take that to a lichened slab. Don't worry. It's still fun. Don't miss the opportunity to tie off the big chickenhead. Get some gear under the short roof and bail right to the corner so as to avoid the Horse Pens topout through pine needles. Descend from cord in the tree.
content.protection: A wide variety of options, longer slings recommended.
content.location: Just downstream and around the corner from the Tabasco routes.

content.description: Bring your double-length runners for this one.  This route starts up the friendly holds of the beginning of Wooshka Man to a ledge.  From the ledge, traverse right (although the moves are easy, remember to protect your second on the traverse, as the ledge isn't a great distance off the ground) to an obvious right-angling weakness.  Follow this weakness with plentiful pro up and right until you link up with the plated jugs of Truancy and finish it to the anchors.
content.protection: Rack up to #2 Camalot.  Plentiful pro throughout.  Shared 2 bolt anchor with Truancy.
content.location: 35 or so feet downstream from Truancy.  The route starts at Wooshka Man- an obvious bulge slightly downhill from Truancy.

content.description: Start at a tree growing out of a small ledge.  Large hueco to the right of the tree about 12 feet up.  Climb thin crimps and small holds until you gain a ledge 20 feet up.  From the ledge, 40 feet or so of gorgeous crack and friendly holds lead you to more good holds in the form of plated jugs and some face climbing. Head for a notch in the lip of the cliff.
content.protection: The crack offers plentiful pro of almost any size from 3 to .3. Â Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Immediately left of Piss Pot Ledge.  You can't miss the start of the route, as it is marked by a tree and a large hueco and an obvious notch in the lip of the cliff with a large tree at the top.  Left end of Moon Wall.  If you walk until the fire road gets close to the rock at the far end of Lower Meadow, you've gone too far.

content.description: This is a real hidden gem for the 5.10 trad climber.   The entire route has excellent pro and thought provoking moves the entire way.   Climb up some broken ledges to reach a protruding flake (you can sling this for some bomber natural pro).   Grab the flake and pull the overhang staying left of some mountain laurel to reach a ledge.  From here, wander right and left following the path of least resistance.  The crux comes at mid height as you make the first traverse to the left side of the arete.   Follow very positive holds and plates to the finish.
content.protection: A standard rack up to a #2 or #3 Camalot. Mostly mid sized gear. New bolted anchors with rap rings
content.location: Continue walking left along the Moon Wall.   When you pass the 2nd waterfall (if it's flowing) continue past some rotten rock until the buttress begins to improve (approximately 100 yds past the waterfall).   Locate the arete with a juggy overhang at the start about 20 feet up.

content.description: Steep and fun, this route is largely a romp on plate jugs. Protection can be challenging, so don't rip off any of the jugs!
content.protection: Gear to 4", possibly an extra long sling or two for slinging chickenheads. Rap from the tree above.
content.location: Start as for Tobasco Fur.  Above the vegetation trend right via a crack.  When the crack peters out, venture up and left on giant plate jugs to join Tabasco Fur.

content.description:
This is listed as a project

Easy to Slip

in the Williams guidebook, the crux is low, but pulling the top is pretty rough, you will need to rappel off a tree up top and donate some blood while crawling through thorn bushes.
content.protection: Small gear and a #2 for up high. No anchor.
content.location: The route is on the same ledge system as Making Whoopie, the climb goes up a left leaning crack that cuts orange and gray rock. The FA was done as a direct line straight up, but access is most commonly gained on the left side.

content.description: Start up the giant v slot and climb into the dark depths of the Room of Doom. Play a daring game of the-floor-is-lava to cross the Room, then solve the final riddle to escape to a finishing roof pull.
content.protection: standard rack, offwidth gear unnecessary
content.location: It's the most obvious v slot to room of doom around. Let of Wooshka Man

content.description: Climb the face with plated pockets 20 ft right of Little Feat.
content.protection: Gear.  Has new bolted anchors.

content.description:
If you want to avoid the Room of Doom, here's how you go around it! But unlike this route's counterpart whitewater rapid, you should probably just go into the Room of Doom because it's more awesome, more direct, and safer.

Start on either Room of Doom or Modern Guilt to access the large ledge left of ROD. Face climb with finnicky gear up and right then pull the bulge to the anchors of Room of Doom
content.protection: standard. borderline marginal off the ledge

content.description: This is the better of the two ledge access routes. The climbing is juggy and casual, the protection is a little more intricate as it is face climbing.
content.protection: Standard rack with a few slings to sling heads. No anchor.
content.location: Pickled Eggs starts about ten feet left of 'Ledge Access', start on the same small ledge traverse left and follow the path of least resistance up the juggy chicken heads and plates.

content.description:
This is really a great "sport" route that happens to be missing a bolt (but instead has a perfect mail slot to put a small cam in).

The first bolt is fairly high, another small cam can be used to protect the moves up to it.  Then climb straight up, making long moves between good holds, with several nice rests.  The balancy crux at the end is awesome!
content.protection:
4 bolts, but you should bring a few small cams to protect the runout after the 3rd bolt (the guidebook is incorrect).

The 2-bolt anchor is shared with Bust a Move.
content.location: Right of Bust a Move, near the waterfall.

content.description:
Stick clip the first bolt, and climb through the thin seams that punctuate the incredibly smooth brown face. The crux is between the fourth and fifth bolts, after which a 10 foot section of finger crack leads to the anchors.

This route has some of the smoothest rock in the area. It requires confident footwork, a very long reach, and a flexible interpretation of the official 5.12b grading.
content.protection: 5 bolts + a few small to medium nuts.
content.location: First route to the left of the Winter Harvest Arete. Starts on a ledge -- look for the line of bolts above a mushroom-shaped feature.

content.description: Climbs the plated crack.
content.protection: Gear.  Has new bolted anchors.
content.location: Starts from the right end of Piss Pot ledge.

content.description: It's in the guidebook, but skip this POS! Not much pro, bad belay options, dirty topout with thorn bushes and a tree with no anchor 20' back.
content.protection: If you really want to climb this, a standard rack is fine but you won't use much of it.

content.description: Juggy, plated face that is vertical.
content.protection: Gear.  Has new bolted anchors.
content.location: 10 feet right of Giggle Box, shares anchors with it

content.description: The crux is stemming to gain the hand crack. The climb is short and sweet and over when you slam your first hand jam.
content.protection: A few hand sized cams, no anchor.
content.location: The climb starts atop an easy scramble, climbing into a wide chimney crack low and opening into a hand crack shortly thereafter. End atop a ledge & rappel off a rock.

content.description: This is an extension or second pitch, but is easily done in a single pitch. The climbing on the upper crack from the ledge is very fun and juggy for a trad route.
content.protection: Standard rack to bolt anchor.
content.location: Climb 'Ledge Access' or 'Pickled Eggs' to get to the ledge and climb the fun plated crack on the right end of the ledge.

content.description: Hueco the Flood climbs some delicate moves at the start and finish, the middle is good plated huecos, the top stays a bit dirty from run off.
content.protection: Smaller cams, tri cams & slings. Tree anchor.
content.location: This climbs starts atop the ledge, climbers left of 'Jugnasium' in the middle of the face aim for the huecos up higher and get gear in the middle. avoid slinging the chicken heads as they seem frail...

content.description: A very nice face climb for the confident 5.9 trad leader! Climb straight up the face on really cool huecos, taking pro where you can get it.
content.protection:
New bolted anchor thanks to NRAC.

There is a bit of a runout around the middle part, I would call it PG-13.
content.location: Between Truancy and the Piss Pot Ledge.

climbs.name: Golden Age
climbs.fa: Eddie Begoon, Kenny Parker Kevin Parker

content.description: This is a very good pure stemming corner, which is rare at the NRG.  Clip the first two bolts of the sport arete Winter Harvest, but instead of going left, head straight up the obvious corner.  It is a bit spicy through here, until you clip a Thank-God bolt, which protects the crux.
content.protection: 3 bolts, small gear.
content.location: Obvious dihedral at the right end of Moon Wall, left of Off My Rocker and just right of Winter Harvest.

content.description: Climbs wide crack at the left end of the right hand ledge of Piss Pot Ledge.  Starts off the ledge. Lots of jugs.
content.protection: Gear.  Has new bolted anchors.
content.location: Climb easy wide crack to Piss Pot ledge.

content.description: This route is a ton of fun with easy juggy climbing. Get a better than a bolt stopper right at the roof and pull over on big holds. Romp up the crack laden with plates and jugs. Finish at the two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Standard rack, new bolted anchors.
content.location: Left of Winter Harvest on a small ledge. Obvious crack out the roof above some shattered rock

content.description: This is a high quality route this is likely overlooked.   Excellent moves that link perfectly.   Start directly under the high first bolt and climb straight up using positive holds to gain the large ledge below the first bolt.   From here, follow a flake to the 2nd bolt, traverse right hand over hand and then head up to reach the 3rd bolt.   A thin section leading to the 4th bolt is the crux.   Diagonal up and right along jugs to reach the shuts.
content.protection: 4 bolts, shuts.   .75 Camalot works well to protect the area before the first bolt.
content.location: This is the left of the 2 lines on the white face capped by a large roof, just to the left of a waterfall after passing the Mango Tango Arete and Back to Power.   It's also about 20 yards to the right of Winter Harvest.
